message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Dynamic Event-Triggered Consensus Control for Interval Type-2 Fuzzy Multi-Agent Systems
Paper Abstract: This study investigates a fuzzy consensus problem for nonlinear multi-agent systems (MASs) with parameter uncertainties via dynamic event-triggered mechanism. The interval type-2 (IT2) fuzzy systems are used to model MASs, and a dynamic event-triggered fuzzy controller is presented. A Lyapunov-Krasovskii functional is constructed in which the sampling property is included, based on which the sufficient condition is determined for dynamic event-triggered fuzzy controller, while all agents are guaranteed to be consensus exponentially. Finally, the MASs of tunnel diode circuit and one-link manipulator are used to verify the efficiency of the presented control method, respectively.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Web search results for query: "multi-agent systems"

Links: [{"title":"Category:Multi-agent systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Multi-agent_systems"},{"title":"Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Autonomous Agents and Multi-Agent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_Agents_and_Multi-Agent_Systems"},{"title":"Distributed multi-agent reasoning system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_multi-agent_reasoning_system"},{"title":"International Conference on Autonomous Agents and Multiagent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Conference_on_Autonomous_Agents_and_Multiagent_Systems"},{"title":"// - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jason_(multi-agent_systems_development_platform)"},{"title":"Multi-agent reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Consensus dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_dynamics"},{"title":"Java Agent Development Framework - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Java_Agent_Development_Framework"},{"title":"Distributed artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_artificial_intelligence"}]

Here are the search results for "multi-agent systems":

## Overview

A multi-agent system (MAS or "self-organized system") is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.(no content)Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.

## Key Characteristics

Agents in a multi-agent system have autonomy (agents are at least partially independent, self-aware, and autonomous) and operate under decentralization (no agent is designated as controlling). Multi-agent systems can manifest self-organisation as well as self-direction and other control paradigms even when individual agent strategies are simple.

## Applications and Areas

Applications where multi-agent systems research may deliver an appropriate approach include online trading, disaster response, target surveillance and social structure modelling.(no content)With advancements in large language models (LLMs), LLM-based multi-agent systems have emerged as a new area of research, enabling more sophisticated interactions and coordination among agents.

## Related Concepts

Multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) is a sub-field of reinforcement learning that focuses on studying the behavior of multiple learning agents that coexist in a shared environment.

The search results also reveal that there are established academic conferences, journals, and development frameworks dedicated to multi-agent systems research, including the AAMAS conference and various software platforms for implementing MAS.

Zadeh - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lotfi_A._Zadeh"}]

Here are the search results for **fuzzy logic**:

## Definition and Core Concepts

Fuzzy logic is a form of many-valued logic in which the truth value of variables may be any real number between 0 and 1.(no content)It is employed to handle the concept of partial truth, where the truth value may range between completely true and completely false. This contrasts with classical Boolean logic, which only allows truth values of 0 (false) or 1 (true).

## History and Development

The term fuzzy logic was introduced with the 1965 proposal of fuzzy set theory by mathematician Lotfi Zadeh.(no content)Basic fuzzy logic had, however, been studied since the 1920s, as infinite-valued logic—notably by Łukasiewicz and Tarski.

## Practical Foundation

Fuzzy logic is based on the observation that people make decisions based on imprecise and non-numerical information.(no content)Fuzzy models or fuzzy sets are mathematical means of representing vagueness and imprecise information (hence the term fuzzy).

## Applications

Fuzzy logic has been applied to many fields, from control theory to artificial intelligence.(no content)Fuzzy logic is used in control systems to allow experts to contribute vague rules such as "if you are close to the destination station and moving fast, increase the train's brake pressure".

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Lyapunov stability"

Links: [{"title":"Lyapunov stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_stability"},{"title":"Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"Lyapunov equation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_equation"},{"title":"Lyapunov optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_optimization"},{"title":"Lyapunov theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_theorem"},{"title":"Aleksandr Lyapunov - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleksandr_Lyapunov"},{"title":"Input-to-state stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Input-to-state_stability"},{"title":"Control-Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control-Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"LaSalle's invariance principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LaSalle's_invariance_principle"},{"title":"Orbital stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orbital_stability"}]

Here are the search results for "Lyapunov stability":

## Overview

Lyapunov stability is named after Aleksandr Mikhailovich Lyapunov, a Russian mathematician who defended the thesis The General Problem of Stability of Motion at Kharkov University in 1892.(no content)Lyapunov is known for his development of the stability theory of a dynamical system, as well as for his many contributions to mathematical physics and probability theory.

## Key Concepts

Near to a point of equilibrium which is Lyapunov stable the system remains stable under small disturbances. More specifically, Lyapunov stability of an equilibrium means that solutions starting "close enough" to the equilibrium remain close enough, while asymptotic stability means solutions that start close enough not only remain close enough but also eventually converge to the equilibrium.

## Lyapunov Functions

In the theory of ordinary differential equations (ODEs), Lyapunov functions, named after Aleksandr Lyapunov, are scalar functions that may be used to prove the stability of an equilibrium of an ODE.(no content)Lyapunov functions (also called Lyapunov's second method for stability) are important to stability theory of dynamical systems and control theory.

## Historical Context

A. M. Lyapunov was a pioneer in successful endeavors to develop a global approach to the analysis of the stability of nonlinear dynamical systems by comparison with the widely spread local method of linearizing them about points of equilibrium. The theory gained significant attention during the Cold War when it became applicable to aerospace systems and control engineering.

I found comprehensive information about "consensus" across multiple contexts. Here's what the web search revealed:

## General Definition

The word consensus is Latin meaning "agreement, accord", derived from consentire meaning "feel together".(no content)Consensus usually refers to general agreement among a group of people or community.

## Key Areas Where Consensus is Used

**Consensus Decision-Making**: Consensus decision-making, as a self-described practice, originates from several nonviolent, direct action groups that were active in the Civil rights, Peace and Women's movements in the USA during counterculture of the 1960s, and the practice gained popularity in the 1970s through the anti-nuclear movement.

**Computer Science**: In distributed computing and multi-agent systems, consensus involves coordinating processes to reach agreement on some data value that is needed during computation.

**Politics & Democracy**: Consensus democracy is the application of consensus decision-making to the process of legislation in a democracy, characterized by a decision-making structure that involves and takes into account as broad a range of opinions as possible.

**Molecular Biology**: In molecular biology and bioinformatics, the consensus sequence is the calculated sequence of most frequent residues, either nucleotide or amino acid, found at each position in a sequence alignment.

**Philosophy & Reality**: Consensus reality is the generally agreed-upon version of reality within a community or society, shaped by shared experiences and understandings.

I've performed a web search for "control theory." Here are the key findings:

## General Definition

Control theory is a field of control engineering and applied mathematics that deals with the control of dynamical systems, with the aim to develop a model or algorithm governing the application of system inputs to drive the system to a desired state, while minimizing any delay, overshoot, or steady-state error and ensuring a level of control stability.

## How It Works

A controller monitors the controlled process variable and compares it with the reference or set point, with the difference between actual and desired value (called the error signal) applied as feedback to generate a control action to bring the controlled process variable to the same value as the set point.

## History

Control theory dates from the 19th century, when the theoretical basis for the operation of governors was first described by James Clerk Maxwell, and was further advanced by Edward Routh, Charles Sturm, Adolf Hurwitz, and Nicolas Minorsky who all contributed to control stability criteria and PID control theory development.

## Applications

Control theory is used in control system engineering to design automation that have revolutionized manufacturing, aircraft, communications and other industries, and created new fields such as robotics.(no content)Beyond direct engineering applications, control theory is routinely applied to problems in natural and behavioral sciences, and is useful in fields like economics, operations research, and the life sciences.

Links: [{"title":"Exponential stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exponential_stability"},{"title":"Lyapunov stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_stability"},{"title":"Stability theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stability_theory"},{"title":"Linear stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unstable_equilibrium"},{"title":"C0-semigroup - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/C0-semigroup"},{"title":"Exponential integrator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exponential_integrator"},{"title":"Floquet theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Floquet_theory"},{"title":"Metzler matrix - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metzler_matrix"},{"title":"Stable distribution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stable_distribution"},{"title":"Lyapunov exponent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_exponent"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of **exponential stability**:

## Definition

Exponential stability is a form of asymptotic stability, valid for more general dynamical systems. More specifically, exponential stability means that solutions not only converge, but in fact converge faster than or at least as fast as a particular known rate.

## Criteria for Linear Time-Invariant Systems

For control theory applications, there are specific criteria:

- **Continuous-time systems**: A continuous linear time-invariant system (LTI) is exponentially stable if and only if the system has eigenvalues (i.e., the poles of input-to-output systems) with strictly negative real parts (i.e., in the left half of the complex plane).

- **Discrete-time systems**: A discrete-time input-to-output LTI system is exponentially stable if and only if the poles of its transfer function lie strictly within the unit circle centered on the origin of the complex plane.

## Non-LTI Systems

Systems that are not LTI are exponentially stable if their convergence is bounded by exponential decay.

## Practical Implications

An exponentially stable LTI system is one that will not "blow up" (i.e., give an unbounded output) when given a finite input or non-zero initial condition. Moreover, if the system is given a fixed, finite input (i.e., a step), then any resulting oscillations in the output will decay at an exponential rate.

Links: [{"title":"Exponential stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exponential_stability"},{"title":"Lyapunov stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_stability"},{"title":"Stability theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stability_theory"},{"title":"Linear stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unstable_equilibrium"},{"title":"C0-semigroup - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/C0-semigroup"},{"title":"Exponential integrator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exponential_integrator"},{"title":"Floquet theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Floquet_theory"},{"title":"Metzler matrix - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metzler_matrix"},{"title":"Stable distribution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stable_distribution"},{"title":"Lyapunov exponent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_exponent"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of **exponential stability**:

## Definition

Exponential stability is a form of asymptotic stability, valid for more general dynamical systems. More specifically, exponential stability means that solutions not only converge, but in fact converge faster than or at least as fast as a particular known rate.

## Criteria for Linear Time-Invariant Systems

For control theory applications, there are specific criteria:

- **Continuous-time systems**: A continuous linear time-invariant system (LTI) is exponentially stable if and only if the system has eigenvalues (i.e., the poles of input-to-output systems) with strictly negative real parts (i.e., in the left half of the complex plane).

- **Discrete-time systems**: A discrete-time input-to-output LTI system is exponentially stable if and only if the poles of its transfer function lie strictly within the unit circle centered on the origin of the complex plane.

## Non-LTI Systems

Systems that are not LTI are exponentially stable if their convergence is bounded by exponential decay.

## Practical Implications

An exponentially stable LTI system is one that will not "blow up" (i.e., give an unbounded output) when given a finite input or non-zero initial condition. Moreover, if the system is given a fixed, finite input (i.e., a step), then any resulting oscillations in the output will decay at an exponential rate.

Links: [{"title":"Time-triggered architecture - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time-triggered_architecture"},{"title":"Time-Triggered Protocol - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time-Triggered_Protocol"},{"title":"Event (computing) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Event_handler"},{"title":"Maurice Heemels - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maurice_Heemels"},{"title":"DOM event - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DOM_Events"},{"title":"Event-driven programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Event-driven_programming"},{"title":"Event-driven architecture - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Event-driven_architecture"},{"title":"Event-driven process chain - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Event-driven_process_chain"},{"title":"Inversion of control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inversion_of_control"},{"title":"Trauma trigger - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trigger_warnings"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about event-triggered control:

The search results indicate that event-triggered systems are an area of research recognized by the IEEE, with contributions to the analysis and design of hybrid, networked, and event-triggered systems. However, the search results don't contain detailed technical information specifically about event-triggered control as a control systems concept.

The results do show related concepts like:

- Time-triggered architecture, a computer system that executes tasks according to a predetermined schedule, which represents an alternative approach to event-triggered systems
- In event-driven applications, there is generally an event loop that listens for events and then triggers a callback function when one of those events is detected

Event-triggered control is a specialized control theory topic that involves triggering control actions based on events rather than at fixed time intervals. This would be more thoroughly covered in academic control theory literature than in the general web sources returned. If you need more detailed technical information about event-triggered control, I'd recommend searching academic databases or control theory textbooks for more specialized resources.

message_text:
## Summary

I've successfully completed the analysis of the paper "Dynamic Event-Triggered Consensus Control for Interval Type-2 Fuzzy Multi-Agent Systems". Here's what was accomplished:

**Paper Classification:** `contribution` - The paper proposes novel techniques including a dynamic event-triggered fuzzy controller and control methodology.

**Extracted and Validated Triples (7 total):**

1. **Multi-agent system** (concept, uses) - Framework for the consensus problem
2. **Fuzzy logic** (concept, uses) - Interval type-2 fuzzy systems used for modeling
3. **Consensus (computer science)** (task, uses) - Primary control objective
4. **Lyapunov stability** (method, uses) - Mathematical analysis tool for stability proof
5. **Exponential stability** (concept, uses) - Guarantees for agent consensus
6. **Control theory** (concept, uses) - Foundation for controller design
7. **Event-driven programming** (method, proposes) - Novel dynamic event-triggered mechanism

All validation checks passed successfully. The file `triples_output.json` has been updated with proper Wikipedia URLs, entity types, relationships, and relevance descriptions.

Sources:
- [Multi-agent system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_system)
- [Fuzzy logic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fuzzy_logic)
- [Consensus (computer science)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_(computer_science))
- [Lyapunov stability](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_stability)
- [Exponential stability](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exponential_stability)
- [Control theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory)
- [Event-driven programming](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Event-driven_programming)
